articles.headline: Markets Up After a Deal by Merrill
articles.snippet: Shares rose on Monday after an investment deal raised hopes that wealthy foreign investors would come to the rescue of America’s ailing investment firms.
articles.abstract: Shares rose on Monday after an investment deal raised hopes that wealthy foreign investors would come to the rescue of America’s ailing investment firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares rose on Monday after a billion-dollar investment deal between Merrill Lynch and the Singapore government raised hopes that wealthy foreign investors would come to the rescue of America’s ailing investment firms.

articles.headline: Georgia School as a Laboratory for Getting Along
articles.snippet: At an unusual elementary school outside Atlanta, more than half the 380 students are refugees from some 40 countries.
articles.abstract: At an unusual elementary school outside Atlanta, more than half the 380 students are refugees from some 40 countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga.  Parents at an elementary school here gathered last Thursday afternoon with a holiday mission: to prepare boxes of food for needy families fleeing some of the world’s horrific civil wars.

articles.headline: Merrill Lynch Sells Stake to Singapore Firm
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch agreed on Monday to sell $5 billion of new stock to an investor from Singapore and a smaller stake to a domestic firm.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch agreed on Monday to sell $5 billion of new stock to an investor from Singapore and a smaller stake to a domestic firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch became the latest Wall Street bank to grab a financial lifeline from a foreign government, agreeing on Monday to sell $5 billion of new stock to an investor from Singapore and a smaller stake to a domestic firm, as the fallout from mortgage mess continues to spread.

articles.headline: A Threat So Big, Academics Try Collaboration
articles.snippet: Scholars from different disciplines are crossing lines to share ideas about reducing the threat of climate change.
articles.abstract: Scholars from different disciplines are crossing lines to share ideas about reducing the threat of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a basic tenet of university research: Economists conduct joint studies, chemists join forces in the laboratory, political scientists share ideas about other cultures  but rarely do the researchers cross disciplinary lines.

articles.headline: Democrats Try to Rein In Fees on Consulting
articles.snippet: Resentment has been building at how presidential elections have become gold mines for media consultants.
articles.abstract: Resentment has been building at how presidential elections have become gold mines for media consultants.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 2004, and Senator John Kerry had just secured the Democratic presidential nomination. But as huge sums of money began pouring into his campaign, his top strategists had more on their minds than just getting ready for a tough race against President Bush.

articles.headline: It’s Downhill for Sleds, Lamentably
articles.snippet: Toy retailers across the country have largely pushed sleds and toboggans off their shelves and out of their catalog pages, victims of warmer weather and the changing taste of children.
articles.abstract: Toy retailers across the country have largely pushed sleds and toboggans off their shelves and out of their catalog pages, victims of warmer weather and the changing taste of children.
articles.lead_paragraph: These are desperate times for sledding and its urban fans.

articles.headline: States’ Widening of Health Care Hits Roadblocks
articles.snippet: The governors of California, Illinois and Pennsylvania proposed sweeping plans to restructure health care this year, but none will finish 2007 having signed a bill.
articles.abstract: The governors of California, Illinois and Pennsylvania proposed sweeping plans to restructure health care this year, but none will finish 2007 having signed a bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO  A year that began with great ambition for major expansions of health insurance here and in other state capitals is ending with considerable uncertainty, as a second wave of change runs headlong into a darkening economy and political divisions over how to apportion the cost.

articles.headline: Doubts Engulf an American Aid Plan for Pakistan
articles.snippet: The ambitious $750 million plan is imperiled by questions about whether the money could fall into the wrong hands.
articles.abstract: The ambitious $750 million plan is imperiled by questions about whether the money could fall into the wrong hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Weeks before it is to begin, an ambitious American aid plan to counter militancy in Pakistan’s tribal areas is threatened by important unresolved questions about who will monitor the money and whether it could fall into the wrong hands, according to American and Pakistani officials and analysts familiar with the plan.
